title: Judge Blocks Rules Letting Employers Opt Out of Covering Birth Control
summary: Trump administration had revised regulations to let companies with religious or moral objections not offer such insurance plans. A federal judge temporarily blocked a revised set of Trump administration rules allowing employers with religious or moral objections to opt out of providing their workers with health insurance that covers birth control.

title: U.S. Considers Harshest Venezuela Sanctions Yet, on Oil
summary: Washington eyes punitive actions on state-oil firm PdVSA and military. CARACAS-The U.S. is evaluating whether to impose tougher sanctions against Venezuela's military and vital oil industry, a senior Trump administration official said Monday, as it seeks to ratchet up pressure on authoritarian leader Nicolás Maduro to hold free and fair elections.

title: PG&E Was a Hedge-Fund Darling. That Bet Flopped.
summary: Since the November fire, PG&E shares have plunged, challenging the idea that utilities are a safe bet. Utilities have long been considered ultrasafe bets. But PG&E Corp.'s announcement Monday that it will file for bankruptcy is teaching investors that isn't always true.

title: Trump's Mideast Strategy
summary: Like Obama, he wants the U.S. to step back. Unlike Obama, he wants to contain Iran.. As Secretary of State Mike Pompeo concludes his swing through the Middle East, the Trump administration's regional strategy is coming into view. Like President Obama, President Trump wants to reduce American commitments while promoting stability. But their strategies differ. Mr. Obama thought the best hope for a reduced U.S. footprint was conciliating Iran. Mr. Trump, by contrast, seeks to build a coalition of U.S. regional allies-even if those allies fall well short of perfection-that can provide a stable security architecture and offset Iranian strength as the U.S. steps back.

title: Dale Carnegie and the Parking Attendant
summary: An employee inspired a Florida resort owner to an act of grace.. On Gulf of Mexico Drive in Longboat Key, Fla., I rode past the wreckage of the Colony Beach and Tennis Resort. Once the No. 1-ranked tennis destination in the U.S., its buildings have recently been leveled to make room for a planned new development.

title: Mitch McConnell Rules
summary: The Senate majority leader's low-key shutdown strategy is working.. In the daily headlines, the government shutdown-now the longest in American history-is reported as a clash between two uncompromising forces: President Trump and Speaker Nancy Pelosi. In this battle, however, the most important general may be the one who's escaped almost all notice. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has put on full display his penchant for knowing when the best course is to do nothing.

title: 'The Age of Surveillance Capitalism' Review: The New Big Brother
summary: Tech companies have shown themselves to be increasingly cavalier with our personal data. Are we handing over too much information? Frank Rose reviews "The Age of Surveillance Capitalism" by Shoshana Zuboff.. According to Google's Ngram Viewer, which measures the appearance in books of a given phrase over time, the word "surveillance"-from the French sur + veiller, "to watch over"-saw relatively little use until about 1960. At that point, sparked perhaps by the Cold War, it started turning up more and more frequently, a trend that continues to this day. Expect that trend to kick into overdrive now that Shoshana Zuboff's "The Age of Surveillance Capitalism" is out, for hers is the rare volume that puts a name on a problem just as it becomes critical-in this case, the quandary raised by Google and Facebook when they figured out how to fashion the data exhaust of our everyday lives into, as she puts it, "prediction products": little oracles that anticipate our intentions and offer them up to anyone willing to pay.

title: L.A. Schools Have a Math Problem
summary: By going on strike, the teachers union makes it even harder to increase wages and staffing.. Here's a problem that a high-school economics teacher in Los Angeles would relish under different circumstances: Farmer Bob has been growing potatoes for decades, but now the market is shifting, and Bob's $8 billion business is losing nearly $500 million a year. Bob agreed years ago to provide his workers generous health-care and pension benefits in exchange for paying them lower wages. Bob's employees have gone on strike, demanding more money and additional workers.

summary: Musicians have helped spur an antiestablishment moment that could loosen Putin's grip on the culture.. Moscow

summary: The ad-supported service would be offered free to 52 million pay-TV subscribers. title: Debt Denial Is a Threat to America
summary: 'Modern monetary theory' rests on dangerous, false premises. The U.S. won't grow its way out of the red.. Do deficits matter? Between Republican tax cuts and Democratic spending proposals, U.S. lawmakers act as if the answer is no. Lately, academic economists have echoed the sentiment, advocating large, unfunded infrastructure spending programs-the main thrust of former International Monetary Fund chief economist Olivier Blanchard's recent presidential address to the American Economic Association. "Put bluntly," Mr. Blanchard said, "public debt may have no fiscal cost."

title: China Sentences Canadian to Death for Drug Conviction
summary: Legal experts see move as effort to pressure Canada over its arrest of Huawei executive; Canada's Trudeau expresses extreme concern. title: May's Brexit Deal Faces Likely Defeat as Deadline Nears
summary: Vote is expected to leave U.K.'s prime minister in political turmoil 10 weeks before scheduled departure. British Prime Minister Theresa May faces a likely heavy defeat in a vote Tuesday on her plan to leave the European Union, setting the stage for further political turmoil that will test the U.K.'s historically stable political institutions and arcane constitution.

title: What Barr Knows About Firing an FBI Head
summary: He helped bring about the dismissal of William Sessions, the only director before Comey to be sacked.. Mr. Schumer cited a 19-page memo Mr. Barr wrote last June arguing that Mr. Trump couldn't be prosecuted for obstruction of justice over the 2017 firing of James Comey as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But Bill Barr knows something about firing an FBI director. He's one of the few people who have been involved in doing so.

Sprouse, who is currently filming season 3 of the CW series Riverdale and stars in the romantic drama Five Feet Apart, out in March, has a growing career as a photographer. "Some were loud and boisterous, some were quiet and awkward."

Bank stores are suffering, too.

title: Inside the Bizarre Life of a Male Street-Style Star
summary: At the Pitti Uomo trade show in Florence, men come from the around the world not to conduct business, but to be photographed in extravagant outfits. AUSTIN MELLA and Joel Vasquez caught my attention on the first day of Pitti Uomo, a men's fashion trade show held twice yearly in Florence, Italy. When I spotted this American duo inside the fair's cobblestoned courtyard, each man wore a flat-brimmed black fedora and a suit the color of produce-figs for Mr. Mella, blueberries on Mr. Vasquez. Unlike the department-store retailers, reporters and brand representatives who attend Pitti Uomo on business, neither man was there for work. Back home in Orlando, Mr. Mella, 25, is a maintenance technician, while Mr. Vasquez, 26, is an aircraft mechanic. They flew halfway around the world on their vacation time for "the love of fashion," as Mr. Vasquez explained, but also to see and be seen. Without any meetings on their agenda and with flashy outfits on their backs, these two men were prime examples of the "Pitti Peacock."

title: Kanye West Donates $10 Million to Art Project
summary: The rapper is donating $10 million to artist James Turrell's Roden Crater Project in an extinct volcano in Arizona. Kanye West embarked on an art pilgrimage last month to the ethereal, glowing light installations of artist James Turrell. BEIJING-The Trump administration's trade tactics, which have piled uncertainty onto a slowing Chinese economy, dented another growth driver last month: China's juggernaut exports.

title: Apple's Pain Isn't Xiaomi's Gain
summary: Resume Subscription. The bad news for smartphone makers has been unending lately: Apple and Samsung both warned this month that their most recent results will be hurt by slowing handset sales. Even though Chinese brands have been chipping away market share from these two giants, they won't be immune from the slowdown.

title: Apple Rattled Markets With China Warning. Who's Next?
summary: After iPhone maker blamed much of its revenue slump on the country's slowing economy, focus shifts to Starbucks, Nike and others with big exposure. When Apple Inc. said China's slowing economy contributed to its late-year sales slump, the news rattled the stocks of other major U.S. companies with big operations in the world's second-largest economy.

title: The Trade Conflict Starts to Bite China
summary: A bleak December confirms the real hit is just arriving now. Chinese exports have been suffering this winter, but until Monday there wasn't much evidence that the trade tussle with the U.S.-rather than slowing global growth-was a major culprit.

title: Iranian Military Cargo Plane Crashes Near Tehran
summary: Sanctions have made it harder for Tehran to buy new planes or spare parts for its aging fleet. An Iranian military cargo plane crashed at an airport outside Tehran on Monday, killing 15 people and spotlighting again the country's patchy air safety record.

title: Jakarta, Manila Lead Recent Rebound in Emerging Asian Stocks
summary: Resume Subscription. Following a tumultuous period of trade disputes and currency weakness, some emerging markets in Asia have rallied in recent months. They have been boosted by dovish comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and a temporary U.S.-China trade truce.

title: U.K. Parliament's Vote on Brexit Deal Explained
summary: The vote is unlikely to produce certainty around Brexit just over two months before Britain is due to leave the EU. LONDON-British lawmakers are set to vote this week on the terms of the divorce deal that Prime Minister Theresa May has spent two years hammering out with the European Union following the 2016 referendum vote to leave the bloc. The vote, which was originally scheduled for December but was pulled at the last minute because of the scale of opposition to the deal, is now set for Tuesday.

title: Cockpit Voice Recorder Recovered From Indonesia's Lion Air Crash
summary: Investigators hope the recorder will shed light on the flight's final moments. JAKARTA, Indonesia-Divers recovered the cockpit voice recorder from a Lion Air jetliner that crashed in the Java Sea in October, officials said, a potentially important step in helping to understand what happened in the minutes before the new Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane went down.

title: Trump Warns Turkey Not to Attack Kurds in Syria
summary: 'Will devastate Turkey economically if they hit Kurds,' the president said on Twitter, while also calling on Kurds not to provoke Ankara. WASHINGTON-President Trump vowed on Sunday to devastate Turkey's economy if it targets Kurdish populations in northern Syria as the U.S. withdraws its forces, and called for a 20-mile safe zone between the Turkish border and U.S.-allied fighters.

title: Blackstone to Start Growth-Investing Business
summary: Private-equity firm hires General Atlantic's Jon Korngold to run the platform. Blackstone Group LP hired away a General Atlantic executive to launch a business that will invest in fast-growing companies.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China Posts Record Trade Surplus With U.S. Despite Tariff Offensive
summary: China posted a trade surplus of $323.32 billion with the U.S. in 2018. BEIJING-China's trade surplus with the U.S. hit a record last year, as robust American demand for Chinese goods undercut the Trump administration's tariff offensive aimed at narrowing the countries' lopsided trade gap.

title: CEO of PG&E Steps Down Amid California Wildfire Crisis
summary: Geisha Williams is leaving the state's largest utility as it faces billions in potential fire liability costs. PG&E Corp. said Sunday that Chief Executive Geisha Williams was stepping down as the company grapples with the growing political and financial fallout of its role in helping spark California wildfires.

title: Ashland to Make Board Changes
summary: Chemicals firm strikes deal with Neuberger Berman; activist Cruiser has been waging a proxy fight. Ashland Global Holdings Inc., locked in a proxy fight with an activist investor, struck a deal with a different, typically quiet investor to add two new directors and make other changes.

title: White House Sought Options to Strike Iran
summary: State and Pentagon officials were rattled by the request. President Trump's National Security Council asked the Pentagon to provide the White House with military options to strike Iran last year, generating concern at the Pentagon and State Department, current and former U.S. officials said.

title: Singapore's CapitaLand Buys Real-Estate Firm for More Than $4 Billion
summary: Resume Subscription. SINGAPORE- CapitaLand Ltd. said it would buy another real-estate company from Singapore state investment firm Temasek Holdings Pte. for more than US$4 billion dollars.

title: NFL's Final Four: Two Generational Showdowns
summary: Patrick Mahomes, Jared Goff, Tom Brady and Drew Brees lead the league's best offenses and will battle as a new era of quarterback takes on the old. Foxborough, Mass.

title: Slow Earnings Growth, Dim Forecasts Weigh on Stocks
summary: String of lowered estimates raises investors' concerns that biggest U.S. companies are losing momentum. The U.S.'s biggest public companies are warning that their earnings may not be as strong as they hoped this year, intensifying pressure on a bull market that has struggled to regain its footing.

title: FAA Plans to Call Inspectors Back to Work
summary: Most flights and airport security screening still unaffected by shutdown, TSA says. The Federal Aviation Administration is gearing up to ask more airline inspectors and other technical employees to return to work in coming days, according to agency and union officials, reflecting efforts to cope with the partial government shutdown.

title: Albany Eyes Campaign-Finance Reform, but Activists Want More
summary: Prominent names including Chris Hughes, Jonathan Soros, Craig Newmark and Alec Baldwin urge leaders against a nibbling approach. Democratic leaders of the New York State Assembly and Senate are set to approve a passel of bills to increase voter participation and tighten campaign-finance laws. But there's still a push to go further on some issues, including the creation of a public-matching system to finance campaigns.

title: Gymboree Expected to File for Bankruptcy for Second Time in Two Years
summary: Children's clothing retailer Gymboree Group is expected to file for bankruptcy protection as soon as this week and will liquidate its stores. Children's clothing retailer Gymboree Group Inc. is expected to seek bankruptcy protection this week, with plans to close all 900 of its stores, according to people familiar with the matter.
